Literature Review: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of small non-coding RNAs that play crucial roles in post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression. They are involved in various biological processes, including development, differentiation, and cellular homeostasis. Viruses, particularly double-stranded DNA viruses, have evolved to produce their own small RNAs (sRNAs), including miRNAs, which are known as virus-derived miRNAs (v-miRNAs). These v-miRNAs are instrumental in modulating host cell functions to favor viral replication and persistence, often leading to chronic infections and associated diseases. Several studies have highlighted the importance of v-miRNAs in viral pathogenesis. For instance, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), a member of the herpesvirus family, encodes multiple v-miRNAs that contribute to its ability to establish and maintain latency in host cells. These v-miRNAs target host genes involved in apoptosis, cell cycle regulation, and immune response, thereby promoting viral survival and evasion of host defenses. Similarly, Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) produces v-miRNAs that downregulate pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines, reducing the host's ability to mount an effective immune response. The role of v-miRNAs in chronic stress and inflammation has been extensively studied. Chronic viral infections often lead to persistent activation of the immune system, resulting in chronic inflammation. V-miRNAs can exacerbate this condition by targeting key regulators of the inflammatory response. For example, v-miRNAs from human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) have been shown to downregulate the expression of interferon-stimulated genes, thereby dampening the antiviral state of infected cells. This modulation of the host immune response can lead to prolonged viral persistence and increased risk of developing chronic diseases such as cancer and autoimmune disorders. In addition to their role in immune evasion, v-miRNAs also contribute to the pathogenesis of specific diseases. For instance, EBV-encoded v-miRNAs have been implicated in the development of B-cell lymphomas. These v-miRNAs target tumor suppressor genes and pro-apoptotic factors, promoting cell survival and proliferation. Similarly, v-miRNAs from hepatitis C virus (HCV) have been shown to enhance the expression of genes involved in lipid metabolism, contributing to the development of steatosis and liver fibrosis. Recent advances in bioinformatics have significantly enhanced our understanding of v-miRNAs and their functions. In silico approaches, such as computational prediction algorithms and machine learning models, have been developed to identify and characterize v-miRNAs. These tools can predict potential target genes and pathways regulated by v-miRNAs, providing valuable insights into their biological roles. For example, the use of these bioinformatics tools has led to the discovery of novel v-miRNAs from emerging viruses, such as Zika virus (ZIKV) and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV). Moreover, the integration of experimental data with computational predictions has facilitated the validation of v-miRNA targets and their functional consequences. High-throughput sequencing technologies, such as RNA-seq and ChIP-seq, have been used to profile the transcriptome and epigenome of virus-infected cells, revealing the complex regulatory networks influenced by v-miRNAs. These integrated approaches have not only deepened our understanding of v-miRNA biology but also identified potential therapeutic targets for combating viral infections. In conclusion, v-miRNAs play a critical role in the interaction between viruses and their hosts, influencing various aspects of viral pathogenesis, including immune evasion, chronic inflammation, and disease development. The ongoing advancements in bioinformatics and experimental techniques are expected to further elucidate the mechanisms underlying v-miRNA function and pave the way for the development of novel antiviral strategies. Understanding the intricate interplay between v-miRNAs and host cellular processes is essential for the identification of therapeutic targets and the design of effective interventions against viral diseases.
